I've only played a few turn-based strategy games (though I intend to play a lot more), but Age of Fear felt different from those I have tried – in a good way, for the most part. The tabletop-style maps are not fundamentally all that different from the grid-based battlefields of Fire Emblem and XCOM, but I personally got a warm fuzzy sensation from painstakingly positioning my troops where I thought they would be most effective – plus, the lack of a clearly-defined grid makes human error a more distinct possibility, as there were times when an enemy was able to charge through a gap in my formation that I'd thought I'd sealed up. The fact that each movement can only be conducted in a straight line also forces the player to plan ahead, lest reinforcements end up trapped behind the allies they are trying to save.
  In my experience, most battles will be decided by a massed melee at some point or other, but the three factions have their differences: the Humans have skilled archers, swordsmen and knights, the Orcs – who have no campaign in this game, but are available in Replay Battle mode and Multiplayer – have tough infantry and monsters, and the Undead have a plethora of supernatural units combined with the ability to raise more cannon-fodder from their deceased enemies. In the aftermath, the player is taken to a menu where they can recruit new troops, teach veterans new skills, equip or sell items that have been found or stolen in battle, and purchase other pieces of equipment. The capacity to customise your main heroes is quite extensive, and even your lowlier soldiers can carry a couple of potions, allowing for a wider range of tactical possibilities than I'd originally expected to find.

The visuals are simple but effective; different units are easily recognisable, and although the animations are pretty basic they get the job done. The tabletop-gaming aesthetic serves a useful function, too: in, say, an Undead-versus-Undead battle, your troops will have different coloured bases from your enemies, so you can distinguish between them at a glance. Age of Fear might not be a treat for the eyes, but it's no eyesore either – I'd much rather have functional graphics that work reliably than a glitch-ridden mess, and I'm glad AoF has the former.

The two campaigns each took me around eight hours to complete; the occasional plot-based decision, varying difficulties, hidden secrets and achievements all offer a player excuses for replaying them, if you're that way inclined. As for the stories themselves, the Knight's quest was a tolerable tale of one man and his indignant steed fighting evil wherever he encountered it; the Necromancer's campaign followed the rise, fall, and rise again of an evil mage whose tongue was notably sharper than his wit. Neither story has much narrative depth, but the number of scripted in-game conversations that popped up when various criteria were fulfilled did impress me, even if the actual writing tended to be more 'miss' than 'hit'. To be honest, I was pleasantly surprised to find there were any hits at all – I like to think I'm a rather discerning fellow when it comes to prose and dialogue, and yet some of these short scenes were endearing enough that they brought a smile to my miserable lips.

OVERALL
I played through one campaign of AoF, then the other, and then dived straight into AoF2. I think that's got to be worth a thumbs-up, right? Turn-based fantasy RPGs by small developers are certainly not going to appeal to everyone, but if you think you might be a fan of such a thing, I'd hazard a guess that this is a good game for you.

It proclaims itself as a "perma death" game, but on the difficulties I've played (excluding hard and death seeker, I'm not a great player) you're able to resurrect all your troops by the end of combat, provided they haven't in turn been resurrected by a nearby necromancer. Après avoir fait 6 ou 7 batailles de la première campagne, j'ai eu droit à un dialogue où le roi (complètement out of character) me recommandait d'écrire une review sur ce jeu. J'ai clické sur "Yes I will write a review", j'ai eu un message me disant que j'étais redirigé vers steam pour la poster.... et en suivant un écran noir avec rien à faire pour en sortir à part redémarrer mon ordinateur, d'où la négativité de ma première review.
Tant qu'à pousser les joueurs à en écrire, éviter de le faire à un stade du jeu où ses qualités n'apparaissent pas vraiment (voir plus loin), et s'assurer que la redirection ne crée pas de bug, seraient de bonnes idées.

Plus sérieusement c'est pas un mauvais jeu, dans le registre tactique simple (évoquant pas mal Wesnoth, les hexagones en moins). Et quiconque connait la difficulté de produire de bonnes interfaces graphiques en java peut être assez admiratif de ce que cette petite équipe a réussi à faire avec. 

Le look du jeu, dessin des unités (peut être auraient ils dù suivre la mode et se mettre au pixel art pour cacher les lacunes de leur graphiste) etc... et l'histoire plutôt bateau, agrémentée d'humour potache et présentée sous la forme de longs wall of text entre deux missions font terriblement amateur mais ça s'oublie vite car les batailles sont loin d'être inintéressantes, avec une difficulté bien dosée.

Après si on compare avec des titres comme Wesnoth justement (qui lui est gratuit), ou plus encore des jeux tactiques plus élaborés comme Fallout tactics, Xenonauts, X-Com, Jagged Alliance, etc... difficile de trouver que les quelques choix originaux d'AoF apportent vraiment grand chose. 

Le principal, ne pas avoir de cases, mais avoir des unités qui bloquent le mouvement, même des amis, sur une certaine zone, rend surtout les choses plus confuses. Souvent on se retrouvera avec l'impression que 3 unités peuvent attaquer un ennemi donné, mais après en avoir fait attaquer 2 on se rendra compte que leur position bloque l'accès à la troisième unité. 
Quant aux troupes à distance, une différence de 1 pixel dans leur placement au tour précédent, peut tout changer pour elles, comme elles ne peuvent pas se déplacer et tirer dans le même tour, que leur portée n'est pas énorme (sérieusement il faudrait que les réalisateurs de jeux tactiques se renseignent sur la portée d'un arc un jour), mais qu'elles sont très désavantagées en mélée, leur placement est un casse tête permanent, mais un brin artifiel je trouve.
Enfin alors que l'orientation des unités compte pour certaines attaques (backstab) et influe sur le mouvement des cavaliers (ils ne vont pas aussi loin en faisant un demi tour complet), il n'est pas possible de la choisir en prévision du tour suivant, une unité reste juste tournée dans la dernière direction où elle se déplaçait ou attaquait.

Finalement la structure même du déroulement d'un tour, qui est purement I go you go (je fais agir toutes mes unités puis toi toutes les tiennes) est plutôt pauvre pour un jeu tactique (pas de système d'initiative, d'interruptions, etc). Et d'autant plus qu'il n'y a pas non plus de système d'engagement ou d'attaque d'opportunité (il est possible de quitter une unité contre laquelle on se battait en mélée, de se déplacer normalement et d'en attaquer une autre sans aucun malus ou risque).
Et la structure du tour d'une unité n'est pas mieux (une unité de mélée ne peut faire que déplacement puis attaque ou usage de compétence spéciale, pas l'inverse ; une unité à distance déplacement ou attaque). Par rapport aux jeux à points d'action comme ceux que je citais plus haut, c'est vraiment très pauvre au niveau des choix.

Tout ceci entrainant un gameplay qui est toujours un peu le même aux premiers tours des batailles : on essayera de placer ses troupes juste hors de portée des ennemis, pour les frapper en premier quand ils avanceront (et on peut être certain que l'IA avancera plutôt que de faire la même chose). 
L'efficacité de cette tactique est décuplée par le fait que les unités ont très peu de points de vie (le soldat débutant humain ou gobelin de base en a un et fait un point de dégat), en plaçant bien ses troupes pour agir en premier il est souvent possible d'éliminer directement un paquet d'ennemis sans réplique. 

Le gros de la difficulté devient dès lors de réaliser ce placement offrant un énorme avantage au joueur dans un système sans cases (de mettre au pixel près les unités là où elles doivent être pour avoir un bon choix de cibles au tour suivant sans pour autant s'avancer trop ou bloquer les autres). Ce n'est pas toujours évident mais pas vraiment un type de difficulté faisant appel aux qualités stratégiques du joueur.

This game is fantastic!  It's like playing a tabletop wargame on the PC.  You have a puny force of troops pitted against overwhelming odds and you have to tactically maneuver your way across the battlefield to survive.  Closest existing game I can compare to is the Fire Emblem series but the rules are a lot more like your typical hobby shop miniatures game.  There are dice rolls, linear movement without a ruler, simple stats, few abilities, limited debuffs, only a few health points per troop, everything is kept super simple and obvious so you can understand what's going on across the entire battlefield simultaneously.  This isn't one of those Civilizations turn-based games that will information overload you.  It's easy to predict and understand how a fight will go between two units and I found Ogres scary before ever fighting one just by looking at the stats!  Yet likewise I understood exactly how to beat one just by looking at their abilities versus mine.

This is more about understanding your army and keeping units alive.  If you've played turn-based games like Valkyria Chronicles or XCOM then you should enjoy this.  There's even an ironman mode that prevents save scumming so you have to know how to keep your troops alive.  Since there's no way to farm gold between missions you also have to manage your expenses and not blow too much gold too quickly on units or items or potions.

Great game!  Highly recommended!

This game is also extremely easy to mod, and even includes a basic map editor.  The unit files and campaign files can be easily extracted from the main .jar files using winrar, and are basic text files that can be edited in any ascii editor like notepad+, and then re-compressed into the main game files. overall, game is well worth the price.

Let’s get one thing perfectly clear straight away. You’re not going to be pouring hours upon hours of game time into Leszek Sliwko’s fantastic Age of Fear series because of breathtaking graphics and incredible surround sound. The game simply lacks that. So if you’re a graphics and sound technology whore who has little appreciation for other aspects of games then you’re going to want to turn away now and find a game geared more for you. I personally found that the first Age of Fear game to be a fantastic game crying out to be played. It will hold incredible appeal to those of you who appreciate great game play mechanics and those of you who have a likening to well thought out strategy games that begin simple enough to allow you to learn the basics before gradually increasing the difficulty and mechanics of the game to the point that you’re enveloped in the games cocoon.

The game’s greatest strength is its AI. Many people could take pages out of Sliwko’s book on how to program artificial intelligence, well, intelligently. Many games of this nature fail miserably because the computer is not programmed to play smartly with the game often boiling down to understanding the basic idiosyncrasies of the game before they become a cakewalk. This is simply not the case here. The strategy required to be successful starts outside of the battle. You must select your troops and then evolve them – upgrading their talents and abilities – correctly to enjoy sustained success. Otherwise you will find that you are obliterated. This is a nice low-complexity indie turn-based tactical RPG, with a focus on overcoming tactical battles using a hero and a band of comrades. Graphics are functional top-down 2D graphics, which I thought were decent. Play choices outside of combat are about choosing which types of comrades to join your group, and how to develop their abilities as they gain experience. I didn't see any choices outside of combat, party composition, which special items to give to which characters, and which skills to improve with experience. So it's really a series of tactical battles with text and party management between battles - no other choices, no exploration, etc. Difficulty levels range from easy to Death Seeker. 

I bought it and played only on Death Seeker, because I'm hard core that way - er, actually because I like permadeath and permanent crippling wounds to happen - I might rather have played on a somewhat easier difficulty level, as I ran into situations I failed to overcome (since I accepted defeat and don't savescum). It could be seen as a problem that Death Seeker seemed not terribly hard but then led to a VERY difficult encounter, but if a player doesn't mind re-playing such a scenario, the game does allow shifting the difficulty up and down during a campaign.

Overall I recommend the game if it's a type you might like, as the type of game is one I like a lot, and I mostly enjoyed the content. There are some things I would rather worked differently or were improved, but I'm an old-time gamer with refined tastes.

The Good:
* Turn-based tactical combat with some interesting and semi-realistic elements, combined arms tactics, etc.
* Fun to try to keep men alive and develop their abilities.
* Ability to try various tactics, group types, and different character abilities.
* Variety of tactical situations and opponents.
* Well-written story linking the battles, which gives content and makes sense. (Few typos considering the devs are not native English speakers.)
* The developers are steadily improving the game and they listen to player feedback - a formula which leads to some of the best games, in the long run.

The Medium:
* If you're spoiled by graphics made by corporate games with million-dollar budgets, these are as seen in the screenshots. I thought they were fine.
* I could wish for various improvements and changes to the combat system, but again I have rarified tastes. I like it more than 95% of computer RPGs, so it would seem somewhat silly to complain. With devs like these who listen, the thing to do is send them your suggestions, so I did.
* I saw no option to turn off the random character voice comments when moving each unit, without turning off all the ambient sounds. I grew tired of those voices after a while. P.S. As you can see in the comments, this is an example of something the devlopers are listening to and will be an option to turn off in the next version!

The Bad:
* Nothing I'd call bad.
